Factor graphs better represent the computations needed to do inference
we can write the forward-backward algorithm seen before into a general message passing form
there are two types of message:
from a variable node (    ) to its neighbor factor nodes (    ):
from a factor node (    ) to its neighbor variable nodes (    ):
On a linear chain graph, belief propagation is the same a forward-backward
forward pass of message passing computes the
backward pass of message passing computes the
Can do inference on other types of structures
belief propagation is also exact on arbitrary trees
on a graph with loops, (loopy-)belief propagation can be used to do approximate inference (but can divergence, if not careful)
many general purpose libraries are publicly available
For numerical stability, passing log-messages is preferred

The expectation over y will often need to be approximated, using loopy belief propagation
it will often involve only a few of the yk variables
In general, an approximated marginal is computed by
summing all the log-factors that involve only the yk variables of interest
summing all the log-messages coming into the yk variables from other factors
Why not just change the loss function to a tractable one
predict, in turn, each yk not just from X, but also all the other elements of y
this is because these probabilities only require normalizing yk individually, like in a regular softmax
however, often tends to work less well
we still need to compute p(yk|X) to do predictions anyways
We saw how to compute the gradients in a linear-chain CRF
requires the inference of p(yk|X), p(yk, yk+1|X) (seen previous class)
We saw how to interpret inference as the process of passing messages between variables and factors
allows for a general procedure to do approximate inference on arbitrary graphs
this procedure can be adapted to do approximate inference of the maximum probability assignment (max-product algorithm, not seen)
